EventSubType.documentation:
The event.

The following are the error events:

  • iamFleetRoleInvalid - The Spot Fleet did not have the required permissions either to launch or terminate an instance.

  • launchSpecTemporarilyBlacklisted - The configuration is not valid and several attempts to launch instances have failed. For more information, see the description of the event.

  • spotFleetRequestConfigurationInvalid - The configuration is not valid. For more information, see the description of the event.

  • spotInstanceCountLimitExceeded - You've reached the limit on the number of Spot Instances that you can launch.

The following are the fleetRequestChange events:

  • active - The Spot Fleet has been validated and Amazon EC2 is attempting to maintain the target number of running Spot Instances.

  • cancelled - The Spot Fleet is canceled and has no running Spot Instances. The Spot Fleet will be deleted two days after its instances were terminated.

  • cancelled_running - The Spot Fleet is canceled and does not launch additional Spot Instances. Existing Spot Instances continue to run until they are interrupted or terminated.

  • cancelled_terminating - The Spot Fleet is canceled and its Spot Instances are terminating.

  • expired - The Spot Fleet request has expired. A subsequent event indicates that the instances were terminated, if the request was created with TerminateInstancesWithExpiration set.

  • modify_in_progress - A request to modify the Spot Fleet request was accepted and is in progress.

  • modify_successful - The Spot Fleet request was modified.

  • price_update - The price for a launch configuration was adjusted because it was too high. This change is permanent.

  • submitted - The Spot Fleet request is being evaluated and Amazon EC2 is preparing to launch the target number of Spot Instances.

The following are the instanceChange events:

  • launched - A request was fulfilled and a new instance was launched.

  • terminated - An instance was terminated by the user.

The following are the Information events:

  • launchSpecUnusable - The price in a launch specification is not valid because it is below the Spot price or the Spot price is above the On-Demand price.

  • fleetProgressHalted - The price in every launch specification is not valid. A launch specification might become valid if the Spot price changes.

InstanceId.documentation: The ID of the instance. This information is available only for instanceChange events.

Description.documentation: A description of the resource being exported.

StatusMessage.documentation: The status message related to the export task.

ContainerFormat.documentation: The container format used to combine disk images with metadata (such as OVF). If absent, only the disk image is exported.

S3Bucket.documentation: The S3 bucket for the destination image. The destination bucket must exist and grant WRITE and READ_ACP permissions to the AWS account vm-import-export@amazon.com.

S3Key.documentation: The encryption key for your S3 bucket.

ExportToS3Task.documentation: Describes the format and location for an instance export task.

ContainerFormat.documentation: The container format used to combine disk images with metadata (such as OVF). If absent, only the disk image is exported.

S3Bucket.documentation: The S3 bucket for the destination image. The destination bucket must exist and grant WRITE and READ_ACP permissions to the AWS account vm-import-export@amazon.com.

S3Prefix.documentation: The image is written to a single object in the S3 bucket at the S3 key s3prefix + exportTaskId + '.' + diskImageFormat.

Name.documentation: The name of the filter. Filter names are case-sensitive.

Values.documentation: One or more filter values. Filter values are case-sensitive.

Filter.documentation:
A filter name and value pair that is used to return a more specific list of results from a describe operation. Filters can be used to match a set of resources by specific criteria, such as tags, attributes, or IDs. The filters supported by a describe operation are documented with the describe operation. For example:

  • DescribeAvailabilityZones

  • DescribeImages

  • DescribeInstances

  • DescribeKeyPairs

  • DescribeSecurityGroups

  • DescribeSnapshots

  • DescribeSubnets

  • DescribeTags

  • DescribeVolumes

  • DescribeVpcs

ActivityStatus.documentation: The progress of the EC2 Fleet. If there is an error, the status is error. After all requests are placed, the status is pending_fulfillment. If the size of the EC2 Fleet is equal to or greater than its target capacity, the status is fulfilled. If the size of the EC2 Fleet is decreased, the status is pending_termination while instances are terminating.

CreateTime.documentation: The creation date and time of the EC2 Fleet.

ClientToken.documentation:
Unique, case-sensitive identifier you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. For more information, see Ensuring Idempotency.

Constraints: Maximum 64 ASCII characters

ExcessCapacityTerminationPolicy.documentation: Indicates whether running instances should be terminated if the target capacity of the EC2 Fleet is decreased below the current size of the EC2 Fleet.

FulfilledCapacity.documentation: The number of units fulfilled by this request compared to the set target capacity.

FulfilledOnDemandCapacity.documentation: The number of units fulfilled by this request compared to the set target On-Demand capacity.

TargetCapacitySpecification.documentation: The number of units to request. You can choose to set the target capacity in terms of instances or a performance characteristic that is important to your application workload, such as vCPUs, memory, or I/O. If the request type is maintain, you can specify a target capacity of 0 and add capacity later.

TerminateInstancesWithExpiration.documentation: Indicates whether running instances should be terminated when the EC2 Fleet expires.

Type.documentation: The type of request. Indicates whether the EC2 Fleet only requests the target capacity, or also attempts to maintain it. If you request a certain target capacity, EC2 Fleet only places the required requests; it does not attempt to replenish instances if capacity is diminished, and does not submit requests in alternative capacity pools if capacity is unavailable. To maintain a certain target capacity, EC2 Fleet places the required requests to meet this target capacity. It also automatically replenishes any interrupted Spot Instances. Default: maintain.

ValidFrom.documentation: The start date and time of the request, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ). The default is to start fulfilling the request immediately.

ValidUntil.documentation: The end date and time of the request, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ). At this point, no new instance requests are placed or able to fulfill the request. The default end date is 7 days from the current date.

ReplaceUnhealthyInstances.documentation: Indicates whether EC2 Fleet should replace unhealthy instances.

SpotOptions.documentation: The configuration of Spot Instances in an EC2 Fleet.

OnDemandOptions.documentation: The allocation strategy of On-Demand Instances in an EC2 Fleet.

Tags.documentation: The tags for an EC2 Fleet resource.

Overrides.documentation: Any parameters that you specify override the same parameters in the launch template.

LaunchTemplateSpecification.documentation: The launch template to use. You must specify either the launch template ID or launch template name in the request.

Overrides.documentation: Any parameters that you specify override the same parameters in the launch template.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type.

MaxPrice.documentation: The maximum price per unit hour that you are willing to pay for a Spot Instance.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet in which to launch the instances.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone in which to launch the instances.

WeightedCapacity.documentation: The number of units provided by the specified instance type.

Priority.documentation: The priority for the launch template override. If AllocationStrategy is set to prioritized, EC2 Fleet uses priority to determine which launch template override to use first in fulfilling On-Demand capacity. The highest priority is launched first. Valid values are whole numbers starting at 0. The lower the number, the higher the priority. If no number is set, the override has the lowest priority.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type.

MaxPrice.documentation: The maximum price per unit hour that you are willing to pay for a Spot Instance.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet in which to launch the instances.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone in which to launch the instances.

WeightedCapacity.documentation: The number of units provided by the specified instance type.

Priority.documentation: The priority for the launch template override. If AllocationStrategy is set to prioritized, EC2 Fleet uses priority to determine which launch template override to use first in fulfilling On-Demand capacity. The highest priority is launched first. Valid values are whole numbers starting at 0. The lower the number, the higher the priority. If no number is set, the launch template override has the lowest priority.

LaunchTemplateId.documentation: The ID of the launch template. You must specify either a template ID or a template name.

LaunchTemplateName.documentation: The name of the launch template. You must specify either a template name or a template ID.

Version.documentation: The version number of the launch template. You must specify a version number.
The version number of the launch template.

FleetLaunchTemplateSpecificationRequest.documentation: The launch template to use. You must specify either the launch template ID or launch template name in the request.

CreationTime.documentation: The date and time the flow log was created.

DeliverLogsErrorMessage.documentation: Information about the error that occurred. Rate limited indicates that CloudWatch Logs throttling has been applied for one or more network interfaces, or that you've reached the limit on the number of log groups that you can create. Access error indicates that the IAM role associated with the flow log does not have sufficient permissions to publish to CloudWatch Logs. Unknown error indicates an internal error.

DeliverLogsPermissionArn.documentation: The ARN of the IAM role that posts logs to CloudWatch Logs.

LogGroupName.documentation: The name of the flow log group.

ResourceId.documentation: The ID of the resource on which the flow log was created.

TrafficType.documentation: The type of traffic captured for the flow log.

LogDestinationType.documentation: Specifies the type of destination to which the flow log data is published. Flow log data can be published to CloudWatch Logs or Amazon S3.

LogDestination.documentation: Specifies the destination to which the flow log data is published. Flow log data can be published to an CloudWatch Logs log group or an Amazon S3 bucket. If the flow log publishes to CloudWatch Logs, this element indicates the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the CloudWatch Logs log group to which the data is published. If the flow log publishes to Amazon S3, this element indicates the ARN of the Amazon S3 bucket to which the data is published.

ShellVersion.documentation: The version of the AWS Shell that was used to create the bitstream.

State.documentation: Information about the state of the AFI.

CreateTime.documentation: The date and time the AFI was created.

UpdateTime.documentation: The time of the most recent update to the AFI.

OwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the AFI owner.

OwnerAlias.documentation: The alias of the AFI owner. Possible values include self, amazon, and aws-marketplace.

Code.documentation:
The state. The following are the possible values:

  • pending - AFI bitstream generation is in progress.

  • available - The AFI is available for use.

  • failed - AFI bitstream generation failed.

  • unavailable - The AFI is no longer available for use.

Message.documentation: If the state is failed, this is the error message.

FpgaImageState.documentation: Describes the state of the bitstream generation process for an Amazon FPGA image (AFI).

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Latest.documentation:
When enabled, retrieves the latest console output for the instance.

Default: disabled (false)

Output.documentation: The console output, base64-encoded. If you are using a command line tool, the tool decodes the output for you.

Timestamp.documentation: The time at which the output was last updated.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

WakeUp.documentation: When set to true, acts as keystroke input and wakes up an instance that's in standby or "sleep" mode.

HostIdSet.documentation: The IDs of the Dedicated Hosts with which the reservation is associated.

CurrencyCode.documentation: The currency in which the totalUpfrontPrice and totalHourlyPrice amounts are specified. At this time, the only supported currency is USD.

Purchase.documentation: The purchase information of the Dedicated Host reservation and the Dedicated Hosts associated with it.

TotalHourlyPrice.documentation: The potential total hourly price of the reservation per hour.

TotalUpfrontPrice.documentation: The potential total upfront price. This is billed immediately.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

PasswordData.documentation: The password of the instance. Returns an empty string if the password is not available.

Timestamp.documentation: The time the data was last updated.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

ReservedInstanceIds.documentation: The IDs of the Convertible Reserved Instances to exchange.

TargetConfigurations.documentation: The configuration of the target Convertible Reserved Instance to exchange for your current Convertible Reserved Instances.

IsValidExchange.documentation: If true, the exchange is valid. If false, the exchange cannot be completed.

OutputReservedInstancesWillExpireAt.documentation: The new end date of the reservation term.

PaymentDue.documentation: The total true upfront charge for the exchange.

ReservedInstanceValueRollup.documentation: The cost associated with the Reserved Instance.

ReservedInstanceValueSet.documentation: The configuration of your Convertible Reserved Instances.

TargetConfigurationValueRollup.documentation: The cost associated with the Reserved Instance.

TargetConfigurationValueSet.documentation: The values of the target Convertible Reserved Instances.

ValidationFailureReason.documentation: Describes the reason why the exchange cannot be completed.

GroupName.documentation: The name of the security group.

EventType.documentation:
The event type.

  • error - An error with the Spot Fleet request.

  • fleetRequestChange - A change in the status or configuration of the Spot Fleet request.

  • instanceChange - An instance was launched or terminated.

  • Information - An informational event.

Timestamp.documentation: The date and time of the event, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ).

HistoryRecord.documentation: Describes an event in the history of the Spot Fleet request.

Timestamp.documentation: The date and time of the event, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ).

HistoryRecordEntry.documentation: Describes an event in the history of an EC2 Fleet.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone of the Dedicated Host.

AvailableCapacity.documentation: The number of new instances that can be launched onto the Dedicated Host.

ClientToken.documentation: Unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure idempotency of the request. For more information, see How to Ensure Idempotency in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

HostProperties.documentation: The hardware specifications of the Dedicated Host.

HostReservationId.documentation: The reservation ID of the Dedicated Host. This returns a null response if the Dedicated Host doesn't have an associated reservation.

Instances.documentation: The IDs and instance type that are currently running on the Dedicated Host.

AllocationTime.documentation: The time that the Dedicated Host was allocated.

ReleaseTime.documentation: The time that the Dedicated Host was released.

Tags.documentation: Any tags assigned to the Dedicated Host.

Host.documentation: Describes the properties of the Dedicated Host.

InstanceId.documentation: the IDs of instances that are running on the Dedicated Host.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type size (for example, m3.medium) of the running instance.

HostInstance.documentation: Describes an instance running on a Dedicated Host.

UpfrontPrice.documentation: The upfront price of the offering. Does not apply to No Upfront offerings.

HostOffering.documentation: Details about the Dedicated Host Reservation offering.

Cores.documentation: The number of cores on the Dedicated Host.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type size that the Dedicated Host supports (for example, m3.medium).

Sockets.documentation: The number of sockets on the Dedicated Host.

TotalVCpus.documentation: The number of vCPUs on the Dedicated Host.

Count.documentation: The number of Dedicated Hosts the reservation is associated with.

CurrencyCode.documentation: The currency in which the upfrontPrice and hourlyPrice amounts are specified. At this time, the only supported currency is USD.

Duration.documentation: The length of the reservation's term, specified in seconds. Can be 31536000 (1 year) | 94608000 (3 years).

End.documentation: The date and time that the reservation ends.

HostIdSet.documentation: The IDs of the Dedicated Hosts associated with the reservation.

HostReservationId.documentation: The ID of the reservation that specifies the associated Dedicated Hosts.

InstanceFamily.documentation: The instance family of the Dedicated Host Reservation. The instance family on the Dedicated Host must be the same in order for it to benefit from the reservation.

OfferingId.documentation: The ID of the reservation. This remains the same regardless of which Dedicated Hosts are associated with it.

PaymentOption.documentation: The payment option selected for this reservation.

Start.documentation: The date and time that the reservation started.

HostReservation.documentation: Details about the Dedicated Host Reservation and associated Dedicated Hosts.

Arn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the instance profile.

Timestamp.documentation: The time the IAM instance profile was associated with the instance.

IamInstanceProfileAssociation.documentation: Describes an association between an IAM instance profile and an instance.

Arn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the instance profile.

Code.documentation: The ICMP code. A value of -1 means all codes for the specified ICMP type.

Type.documentation: The ICMP type. A value of -1 means all types.

Deadline.documentation: The date in UTC at which you are permanently switched over to using longer IDs. If a deadline is not yet available for this resource type, this field is not returned.

UseLongIds.documentation: Indicates whether longer IDs (17-character IDs) are enabled for the resource.

IdFormat.documentation: Describes the ID format for a resource.

CreationDate.documentation: The date and time the image was created.

Public.documentation: Indicates whether the image has public launch permissions. The value is true if this image has public launch permissions or false if it has only implicit and explicit launch permissions.

KernelId.documentation: The kernel associated with the image, if any. Only applicable for machine images.

OwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the image owner.

Platform.documentation: The value is Windows for Windows AMIs; otherwise blank.

ProductCodes.documentation: Any product codes associated with the AMI.

RamdiskId.documentation: The RAM disk associated with the image, if any. Only applicable for machine images.

State.documentation: The current state of the AMI. If the state is available, the image is successfully registered and can be used to launch an instance.

Description.documentation: The description of the AMI that was provided during image creation.

EnaSupport.documentation: Specifies whether enhanced networking with ENA is enabled.

ImageOwnerAlias.documentation: The AWS account alias (for example, amazon, self) or the AWS account ID of the AMI owner.

Name.documentation: The name of the AMI that was provided during image creation.

RootDeviceName.documentation: The device name of the root device volume (for example, /dev/sda1).

RootDeviceType.documentation: The type of root device used by the AMI. The AMI can use an EBS volume or an instance store volume.

SriovNetSupport.documentation: Specifies whether enhanced networking with the Intel 82599 Virtual Function interface is enabled.

VirtualizationType.documentation: The type of virtualization of the AMI.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation: One or more block device mapping entries.

Format.documentation:
The format of the disk image being imported.

Valid values: VHD | VMDK | OVA

SnapshotId.documentation: The ID of the EBS snapshot to be used for importing the snapshot.

Url.documentation: The URL to the Amazon S3-based disk image being imported. The URL can either be a https URL (https://..) or an Amazon S3 URL (s3://..)

UserBucket.documentation: The S3 bucket for the disk image.

ImageDiskContainer.documentation: Describes the disk container object for an import image task.

Architecture.documentation:
The architecture of the virtual machine.

Valid values: i386 | x86_64

ClientToken.documentation: The token to enable idempotency for VM import requests.

Description.documentation: A description string for the import image task.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Encrypted.documentation: Specifies whether the destination AMI of the imported image should be encrypted. The default CMK for EBS is used unless you specify a non-default AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) CMK using KmsKeyId. For more information, see Amazon EBS Encryption in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

KmsKeyId.documentation:
An identifier for the AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) customer master key (CMK) to use when creating the encrypted AMI. This parameter is only required if you want to use a non-default CMK; if this parameter is not specified, the default CMK for EBS is used. If a KmsKeyId is specified, the Encrypted flag must also be set.

The CMK identifier may be provided in any of the following formats:

  • Key ID

  • Key alias, in the form alias/ExampleAlias

  • ARN using key ID. The ID ARN contains the arn:aws:kms namespace, followed by the region of the CMK, the AWS account ID of the CMK owner, the key namespace, and then the CMK ID. For example, arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:012345678910:key/abcd1234-a123-456a-a12b-a123b4cd56ef.

  • ARN using key alias. The alias ARN contains the arn:aws:kms namespace, followed by the region of the CMK, the AWS account ID of the CMK owner, the alias namespace, and then the CMK alias. For example, arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:012345678910:alias/ExampleAlias.

AWS parses KmsKeyId asynchronously, meaning that the action you call may appear to complete even though you provided an invalid identifier. This action will eventually report failure.

The specified CMK must exist in the region that the AMI is being copied to.

LicenseType.documentation:
The license type to be used for the Amazon Machine Image (AMI) after importing.

Note: You may only use BYOL if you have existing licenses with rights to use these licenses in a third party cloud like AWS. For more information, see Prerequisites in the VM Import/Export User Guide.

Valid values: AWS | BYOL

Platform.documentation:
The operating system of the virtual machine.

Valid values: Windows | Linux

Encrypted.documentation: Specifies whether the destination snapshot of the imported image should be encrypted. The default CMK for EBS is used unless you specify a non-default AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) CMK using KmsKeyId. For more information, see Amazon EBS Encryption in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

KmsKeyId.documentation:
An identifier for the AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) customer master key (CMK) to use when creating the encrypted snapshot. This parameter is only required if you want to use a non-default CMK; if this parameter is not specified, the default CMK for EBS is used. If a KmsKeyId is specified, the Encrypted flag must also be set.

The CMK identifier may be provided in any of the following formats:

  • Key ID

  • Key alias, in the form alias/ExampleAlias

  • ARN using key ID. The ID ARN contains the arn:aws:kms namespace, followed by the region of the CMK, the AWS account ID of the CMK owner, the key namespace, and then the CMK ID. For example, arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:012345678910:key/abcd1234-a123-456a-a12b-a123b4cd56ef.

  • ARN using key alias. The alias ARN contains the arn:aws:kms namespace, followed by the region of the CMK, the AWS account ID of the CMK owner, the alias namespace, and then the CMK alias. For example, arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:012345678910:alias/ExampleAlias.

AWS parses KmsKeyId asynchronously, meaning that the action you call may appear to complete even though you provided an invalid identifier. This action will eventually report failure.

The specified CMK must exist in the region that the snapshot is being copied to.

PrivateDnsName.documentation:
(IPv4 only) The private DNS hostname name assigned to the instance. This DNS hostname can only be used inside the Amazon EC2 network. This name is not available until the instance enters the running state.

[EC2-VPC] The Amazon-provided DNS server resolves Amazon-provided private DNS hostnames if you've enabled DNS resolution and DNS hostnames in your VPC. If you are not using the Amazon-provided DNS server in your VPC, your custom domain name servers must resolve the hostname as appropriate.

PrivateIpAddress.documentation: The private IPv4 address assigned to the instance.

ProductCodes.documentation: The product codes attached to this instance, if applicable.

PublicDnsName.documentation: (IPv4 only) The public DNS name assigned to the instance. This name is not available until the instance enters the running state. For EC2-VPC, this name is only available if you've enabled DNS hostnames for your VPC.

PublicIpAddress.documentation: The public IPv4 address assigned to the instance, if applicable.

RamdiskId.documentation: The RAM disk associated with this instance, if applicable.

StateTransitionReason.documentation: The reason for the most recent state transition. This might be an empty string.

VpcId.documentation: [EC2-VPC] The ID of the VPC in which the instance is running.

EbsOptimized.documentation: Indicates whether the instance is optimized for Amazon EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS Optimized instance.

IamInstanceProfile.documentation: The IAM instance profile associated with the instance, if applicable.

ElasticGpuAssociations.documentation: The Elastic GPU associated with the instance.

NetworkInterfaces.documentation: [EC2-VPC] One or more network interfaces for the instance.

RootDeviceName.documentation: The device name of the root device volume (for example, /dev/sda1).

RootDeviceType.documentation: The root device type used by the AMI. The AMI can use an EBS volume or an instance store volume.

SecurityGroups.documentation: One or more security groups for the instance.

SourceDestCheck.documentation: Specifies whether to enable an instance launched in a VPC to perform NAT. This controls whether source/destination checking is enabled on the instance. A value of true means that checking is enabled, and false means that checking is disabled. The value must be false for the instance to perform NAT. For more information, see NAT Instances in the Amazon Virtual Private Cloud User Guide.

SpotInstanceRequestId.documentation: If the request is a Spot Instance request, the ID of the request.

SriovNetSupport.documentation: Specifies whether enhanced networking with the Intel 82599 Virtual Function interface is enabled.

StateReason.documentation: The reason for the most recent state transition.

CapacityReservationSpecification.documentation: Information about the Capacity Reservation targeting option.

Groups.documentation: The security groups associated with the instance.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation: The block device mapping of the instance.

DisableApiTermination.documentation: If the value is true, you can't terminate the instance through the Amazon EC2 console, CLI, or API; otherwise, you can.

EnaSupport.documentation: Indicates whether enhanced networking with ENA is enabled.

EbsOptimized.documentation: Indicates whether the instance is optimized for Amazon EBS I/O.

InstanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior.documentation: Indicates whether an instance stops or terminates when you initiate shutdown from the instance (using the operating system command for system shutdown).

RootDeviceName.documentation: The device name of the root device volume (for example, /dev/sda1).

SourceDestCheck.documentation: Indicates whether source/destination checking is enabled. A value of true means that checking is enabled, and false means that checking is disabled. This value must be false for a NAT instance to perform NAT.

SriovNetSupport.documentation: Indicates whether enhanced networking with the Intel 82599 Virtual Function interface is enabled.

Parameters used to automatically set up EBS volumes when the instance is launched.

NoDevice.documentation: suppress the specified device included in the block device mapping.

AvailableCapacity.documentation: The number of instances that can still be launched onto the Dedicated Host.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type size supported by the Dedicated Host.

TotalCapacity.documentation: The total number of instances that can be launched onto the Dedicated Host.

InstanceCapacity.documentation: Information about the instance type that the Dedicated Host supports.

InstanceCount.documentation: The number of listed Reserved Instances in the state specified by the state.

State.documentation: The states of the listed Reserved Instances.

CpuCredits.documentation: The credit option for CPU usage of the instance. Valid values are standard and unlimited.

InstanceCreditSpecification.documentation: Describes the credit option for CPU usage of a T2 or T3 instance.

CpuCredits.documentation: The credit option for CPU usage of the instance. Valid values are standard and unlimited.

InstanceCreditSpecificationRequest.documentation: Describes the credit option for CPU usage of a T2 or T3 instance.

InstanceId.documentation: The ID of the resource being exported.

InstanceMarketOptionsRequest.documentation: Describes the market (purchasing) option for the instances.

Association.documentation: The association information for an Elastic IPv4 associated with the network interface.

Ipv6Addresses.documentation: One or more IPv6 addresses associated with the network interface.

OwnerId.documentation: The ID of the AWS account that created the network interface.

PrivateIpAddress.documentation: The IPv4 address of the network interface within the subnet.

PrivateIpAddresses.documentation: One or more private IPv4 addresses associated with the network interface.

SourceDestCheck.documentation: Indicates whether to validate network traffic to or from this network interface.

Status.documentation: The status of the network interface.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet.

IpOwnerId.documentation: The ID of the owner of the Elastic IP address.

PublicIp.documentation: The public IP address or Elastic IP address bound to the network interface.

InstanceNetworkInterfaceAssociation.documentation: Describes association information for an Elastic IP address (IPv4).

AttachTime.documentation: The time stamp when the attachment initiated.

AttachmentId.documentation: The ID of the network interface attachment.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: Indicates whether the network interface is deleted when the instance is terminated.

DeviceIndex.documentation: The index of the device on the instance for the network interface attachment.

Status.documentation: The attachment state.

AssociatePublicIpAddress.documentation: Indicates whether to assign a public IPv4 address to an instance you launch in a VPC. The public IP address can only be assigned to a network interface for eth0, and can only be assigned to a new network interface, not an existing one. You cannot specify more than one network interface in the request. If launching into a default subnet, the default value is true.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: If set to true, the interface is deleted when the instance is terminated. You can specify true only if creating a new network interface when launching an instance.

Description.documentation: The description of the network interface. Applies only if creating a network interface when launching an instance.

DeviceIndex.documentation: The index of the device on the instance for the network interface attachment. If you are specifying a network interface in a RunInstances request, you must provide the device index.

Groups.documentation: The IDs of the security groups for the network interface. Applies only if creating a network interface when launching an instance.

Ipv6AddressCount.documentation: A number of IPv6 addresses to assign to the network interface. Amazon EC2 chooses the IPv6 addresses from the range of the subnet. You cannot specify this option and the option to assign specific IPv6 addresses in the same request. You can specify this option if you've specified a minimum number of instances to launch.

Ipv6Addresses.documentation: One or more IPv6 addresses to assign to the network interface. You cannot specify this option and the option to assign a number of IPv6 addresses in the same request. You cannot specify this option if you've specified a minimum number of instances to launch.

PrivateIpAddress.documentation: The private IPv4 address of the network interface. Applies only if creating a network interface when launching an instance. You cannot specify this option if you're launching more than one instance in a RunInstances request.

PrivateIpAddresses.documentation: One or more private IPv4 addresses to assign to the network interface. Only one private IPv4 address can be designated as primary. You cannot specify this option if you're launching more than one instance in a RunInstances request.

SecondaryPrivateIpAddressCount.documentation: The number of secondary private IPv4 addresses. You can't specify this option and specify more than one private IP address using the private IP addresses option. You cannot specify this option if you're launching more than one instance in a RunInstances request.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet associated with the network string. Applies only if creating a network interface when launching an instance.

Association.documentation: The association information for an Elastic IP address for the network interface.

Primary.documentation: Indicates whether this IPv4 address is the primary private IP address of the network interface.

PrivateIpAddress.documentation: The private IPv4 address of the network interface.

Code.documentation:
The low byte represents the state. The high byte is used for internal purposes and should be ignored.

  • 0 : pending

  • 16 : running

  • 32 : shutting-down

  • 48 : terminated

  • 64 : stopping

  • 80 : stopped

InstanceState.documentation: Describes the current state of an instance.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone of the instance.

Events.documentation: Any scheduled events associated with the instance.

InstanceState.documentation: The intended state of the instance. DescribeInstanceStatus requires that an instance be in the running state.

InstanceStatus.documentation: Reports impaired functionality that stems from issues internal to the instance, such as impaired reachability.

SystemStatus.documentation: Reports impaired functionality that stems from issues related to the systems that support an instance, such as hardware failures and network connectivity problems.

ImpairedSince.documentation: The time when a status check failed. For an instance that was launched and impaired, this is the time when the instance was launched.

Status.documentation: The status.

Description.documentation:
A description of the event.

After a scheduled event is completed, it can still be described for up to a week. If the event has been completed, this description starts with the following text: [Completed].

NotAfter.documentation: The latest scheduled end time for the event.

NotBefore.documentation: The earliest scheduled start time for the event.

InstanceStatusEvent.documentation: Describes a scheduled event for an instance.

Details.documentation: The system instance health or application instance health.

Status.documentation: The status.

Attachments.documentation: Any VPCs attached to the internet gateway.

Tags.documentation: Any tags assigned to the internet gateway.

State.documentation: The current state of the attachment. For an internet gateway, the state is available when attached to a VPC; otherwise, this value is not returned.

InternetGatewayAttachment.documentation: Describes the attachment of a VPC to an internet gateway or an egress-only internet gateway.

FromPort.documentation: The start of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP/ICMPv6 type number. A value of -1 indicates all ICMP/ICMPv6 types. If you specify all ICMP/ICMPv6 types, you must specify all codes.

IpProtocol.documentation:
The IP protocol name (tcp, udp, icmp) or number (see Protocol Numbers).

[EC2-VPC only] Use -1 to specify all protocols. When authorizing security group rules, specifying -1 or a protocol number other than tcp, udp, icmp, or 58 (ICMPv6) allows traffic on all ports, regardless of any port range you specify. For tcp, udp, and icmp, you must specify a port range. For 58 (ICMPv6), you can optionally specify a port range; if you don't, traffic for all types and codes is allowed when authorizing rules.

Ipv6Ranges.documentation: [EC2-VPC only] One or more IPv6 ranges.

PrefixListIds.documentation: [EC2-VPC only] One or more prefix list IDs for an AWS service. With AuthorizeSecurityGroupEgress, this is the AWS service that you want to access through a VPC endpoint from instances associated with the security group.

ToPort.documentation: The end of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP/ICMPv6 code. A value of -1 indicates all ICMP/ICMPv6 codes for the specified ICMP type. If you specify all ICMP/ICMPv6 types, you must specify all codes.

UserIdGroupPairs.documentation: One or more security group and AWS account ID pairs.

IpPermission.documentation: Describes a set of permissions for a security group rule.

CidrIp.documentation: The IPv4 CIDR range. You can either specify a CIDR range or a source security group, not both. To specify a single IPv4 address, use the /32 prefix length.

Description.documentation:
A description for the security group rule that references this IPv4 address range.

Constraints: Up to 255 characters in length. Allowed characters are a-z, A-Z, 0-9, spaces, and ._-:/()#,@[]+=;{}!$*

CidrIpv6.documentation: The IPv6 CIDR range. You can either specify a CIDR range or a source security group, not both. To specify a single IPv6 address, use the /128 prefix length.

Description.documentation:
A description for the security group rule that references this IPv6 address range.

Constraints: Up to 255 characters in length. Allowed characters are a-z, A-Z, 0-9, spaces, and ._-:/()#,@[]+=;{}!$*

KeyFingerprint.documentation: The SHA-1 digest of the DER encoded private key.

KeyMaterial.documentation: An unencrypted PEM encoded RSA private key.

KeyFingerprint.documentation: If you used CreateKeyPair to create the key pair, this is the SHA-1 digest of the DER encoded private key. If you used ImportKeyPair to provide AWS the public key, this is the MD5 public key fingerprint as specified in section 4 of RFC4716.

Add.documentation: The AWS account ID to add to the list of launch permissions for the AMI.

Remove.documentation: The AWS account ID to remove from the list of launch permissions for the AMI.

UserData.documentation: The Base64-encoded user data for the instance.

SecurityGroups.documentation: One or more security groups. When requesting instances in a VPC, you must specify the IDs of the security groups. When requesting instances in EC2-Classic, you can specify the names or the IDs of the security groups.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation: One or more block device mapping entries.

EbsOptimized.documentation:
Indicates whether the instance is optimized for EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal EBS I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS Optimized instance.

Default: false

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type.

NetworkInterfaces.documentation: One or more network interfaces. If you specify a network interface, you must specify subnet IDs and security group IDs using the network interface.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet in which to launch the instance.

LaunchSpecification.documentation: Describes the launch specification for an instance.

CreatedBy.documentation: The principal that created the launch template.

DefaultVersionNumber.documentation: The version number of the default version of the launch template.

LatestVersionNumber.documentation: The version number of the latest version of the launch template.

Ebs.documentation: Information about the block device for an EBS volume.

NoDevice.documentation: Suppresses the specified device included in the block device mapping of the AMI.

VirtualName.documentation: The virtual device name (ephemeralN). Instance store volumes are numbered starting from 0. An instance type with 2 available instance store volumes can specify mappings for ephemeral0 and ephemeral1. The number of available instance store volumes depends on the instance type. After you connect to the instance, you must mount the volume.

Ebs.documentation: Parameters used to automatically set up EBS volumes when the instance is launched.

NoDevice.documentation: Suppresses the specified device included in the block device mapping of the AMI.

CapacityReservationPreference.documentation:
Indicates the instance's Capacity Reservation preferences. Possible preferences include:

  • open - The instance can run in any open Capacity Reservation that has matching attributes (instance type, platform, Availability Zone).

  • none - The instance avoids running in a Capacity Reservation even if one is available. The instance runs in On-Demand capacity.

LaunchTemplateCapacityReservationSpecifi.documentation: Describes an instance's Capacity Reservation targeting option. You can specify only one option at a time. Use the CapacityReservationPreference parameter to configure the instance to run in On-Demand capacity or to run in any open Capacity Reservation that has matching attributes (instance type, platform, Availability Zone). Use the CapacityReservationTarget parameter to explicitly target a specific Capacity Reservation.

CapacityReservationPreference.documentation:
Indicates the instance's Capacity Reservation preferences. Possible preferences include:

  • open - The instance can run in any open Capacity Reservation that has matching attributes (instance type, platform, Availability Zone).

  • none - The instance avoids running in a Capacity Reservation even if one is available. The instance runs in On-Demand capacity.

LaunchTemplateCapacityReservationSpecifi.documentation: Information about the Capacity Reservation targeting option.

Overrides.documentation: Any parameters that you specify override the same parameters in the launch template.

CoreCount.documentation: The number of CPU cores for the instance.

ThreadsPerCore.documentation: The number of threads per CPU core.

CoreCount.documentation: The number of CPU cores for the instance.

ThreadsPerCore.documentation: The number of threads per CPU core. To disable Intel Hyper-Threading Technology for the instance, specify a value of 1. Otherwise, specify the default value of 2.

LaunchTemplateCpuOptionsRequest.documentation: The CPU options for the instance. Both the core count and threads per core must be specified in the request.

Encrypted.documentation: Indicates whether the EBS volume is encrypted.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: Indicates whether the EBS volume is deleted on instance termination.

Iops.documentation: The number of I/O operations per second (IOPS) that the volume supports.

KmsKeyId.documentation: The ARN of the AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) CMK used for encryption.

VolumeSize.documentation: The size of the volume, in GiB.

LaunchTemplateEbsBlockDevice.documentation: Describes a block device for an EBS volume.

Encrypted.documentation: Indicates whether the EBS volume is encrypted. Encrypted volumes can only be attached to instances that support Amazon EBS encryption. If you are creating a volume from a snapshot, you can't specify an encryption value.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: Indicates whether the EBS volume is deleted on instance termination.

Iops.documentation:
The number of I/O operations per second (IOPS) that the volume supports. For io1, this represents the number of IOPS that are provisioned for the volume. For gp2, this represents the baseline performance of the volume and the rate at which the volume accumulates I/O credits for bursting. For more information about General Purpose SSD baseline performance, I/O credits, and bursting, see Amazon EBS Volume Types in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

Condition: This parameter is required for requests to create io1 volumes; it is not used in requests to create gp2, st1, sc1, or standard volumes.

KmsKeyId.documentation: The ARN of the AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) CMK used for encryption.

VolumeSize.documentation:
The size of the volume, in GiB.

Default: If you're creating the volume from a snapshot and don't specify a volume size, the default is the snapshot size.

LaunchTemplateEbsBlockDeviceRequest.documentation: The parameters for a block device for an EBS volume.

Arn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the instance profile.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the instance profile.

AssociatePublicIpAddress.documentation: Indicates whether to associate a public IPv4 address with eth0 for a new network interface.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: Indicates whether the network interface is deleted when the instance is terminated.

DeviceIndex.documentation: The device index for the network interface attachment.

Groups.documentation: The IDs of one or more security groups.

Ipv6AddressCount.documentation: The number of IPv6 addresses for the network interface.

Ipv6Addresses.documentation: The IPv6 addresses for the network interface.

PrivateIpAddress.documentation: The primary private IPv4 address of the network interface.

SecondaryPrivateIpAddressCount.documentation: The number of secondary private IPv4 addresses for the network interface.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet for the network interface.

AssociatePublicIpAddress.documentation: Associates a public IPv4 address with eth0 for a new network interface.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: Indicates whether the network interface is deleted when the instance is terminated.

DeviceIndex.documentation: The device index for the network interface attachment.

Groups.documentation: The IDs of one or more security groups.

Ipv6AddressCount.documentation: The number of IPv6 addresses to assign to a network interface. Amazon EC2 automatically selects the IPv6 addresses from the subnet range. You can't use this option if specifying specific IPv6 addresses.

Ipv6Addresses.documentation: One or more specific IPv6 addresses from the IPv6 CIDR block range of your subnet. You can't use this option if you're specifying a number of IPv6 addresses.

PrivateIpAddress.documentation: The primary private IPv4 address of the network interface.

SecondaryPrivateIpAddressCount.documentation: The number of secondary private IPv4 addresses to assign to a network interface.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet for the network interface.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type.

SpotPrice.documentation: The maximum price per unit hour that you are willing to pay for a Spot Instance.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet in which to launch the instances.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone in which to launch the instances.

WeightedCapacity.documentation: The number of units provided by the specified instance type.

Priority.documentation: The priority for the launch template override. If OnDemandAllocationStrategy is set to prioritized, Spot Fleet uses priority to determine which launch template override to use first in fulfilling On-Demand capacity. The highest priority is launched first. Valid values are whole numbers starting at 0. The lower the number, the higher the priority. If no number is set, the launch template override has the lowest priority.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone of the instance.

Affinity.documentation: The affinity setting for the instance on the Dedicated Host.

GroupName.documentation: The name of the placement group for the instance.

HostId.documentation: The ID of the Dedicated Host for the instance.

Tenancy.documentation: The tenancy of the instance (if the instance is running in a VPC). An instance with a tenancy of dedicated runs on single-tenant hardware.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone for the instance.

Affinity.documentation: The affinity setting for an instance on a Dedicated Host.

GroupName.documentation: The name of the placement group for the instance.

HostId.documentation: The ID of the Dedicated Host for the instance.

Tenancy.documentation: The tenancy of the instance (if the instance is running in a VPC). An instance with a tenancy of dedicated runs on single-tenant hardware.

Version.documentation:
The version number of the launch template.

Default: The default version for the launch template.

LaunchTemplateSpecification.documentation: The launch template to use. You must specify either the launch template ID or launch template name in the request, but not both.

MaxPrice.documentation: The maximum hourly price you're willing to pay for the Spot Instances.

BlockDurationMinutes.documentation: The required duration for the Spot Instances (also known as Spot blocks), in minutes. This value must be a multiple of 60 (60, 120, 180, 240, 300, or 360).

ValidUntil.documentation: The end date of the request. For a one-time request, the request remains active until all instances launch, the request is canceled, or this date is reached. If the request is persistent, it remains active until it is canceled or this date and time is reached.

InstanceInterruptionBehavior.documentation: The behavior when a Spot Instance is interrupted.

MaxPrice.documentation: The maximum hourly price you're willing to pay for the Spot Instances.

BlockDurationMinutes.documentation: The required duration for the Spot Instances (also known as Spot blocks), in minutes. This value must be a multiple of 60 (60, 120, 180, 240, 300, or 360).

ValidUntil.documentation: The end date of the request. For a one-time request, the request remains active until all instances launch, the request is canceled, or this date is reached. If the request is persistent, it remains active until it is canceled or this date and time is reached. The default end date is 7 days from the current date.

InstanceInterruptionBehavior.documentation: The behavior when a Spot Instance is interrupted. The default is terminate.

LaunchTemplateTagSpecification.documentation: The tag specification for the launch template.

ResourceType.documentation: The type of resource to tag. Currently, the resource types that support tagging on creation are instance and volume. To tag a resource after it has been created, see CreateTags.

Tags.documentation: The tags to apply to the resource.

LaunchTemplateTagSpecificationRequest.documentation: The tags specification for the launch template.

DefaultVersion.documentation: Indicates whether the version is the default version.

Enabled.documentation: Indicates whether detailed monitoring is enabled. Otherwise, basic monitoring is enabled.
Specify true to enable detailed monitoring. Otherwise, basic monitoring is enabled.

LoadBalancersConfig.documentation: Describes the Classic Load Balancers and target groups to attach to a Spot Fleet request.

LoadPermissionModifications.documentation: Describes modifications to the load permissions of an Amazon FPGA image (AFI).

InstanceCount.documentation: The number of instances for which to reserve capacity.

EndDate.documentation:
The date and time at which the Capacity Reservation expires. When a Capacity Reservation expires, the reserved capacity is released and you can no longer launch instances into it. The Capacity Reservation's state changes to expired when it reaches its end date and time.

The Capacity Reservation is cancelled within an hour from the specified time. For example, if you specify 5/31/2019, 13:30:55, the Capacity Reservation is guaranteed to end between 13:30:55 and 14:30:55 on 5/31/2019.

You must provide an EndDate value if EndDateType is limited. Omit EndDate if EndDateType is unlimited.

EndDateType.documentation:
Indicates the way in which the Capacity Reservation ends. A Capacity Reservation can have one of the following end types:

  • unlimited - The Capacity Reservation remains active until you explicitly cancel it. Do not provide an EndDate value if EndDateType is unlimited.

  • limited - The Capacity Reservation expires automatically at a specified date and time. You must provide an EndDate value if EndDateType is limited.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Return.documentation: Information about the Capacity Reservation.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

ExcessCapacityTerminationPolicy.documentation: Indicates whether running instances should be terminated if the total target capacity of the EC2 Fleet is decreased below the current size of the EC2 Fleet.

Return.documentation: Is true if the request succeeds, and an error otherwise.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

UserIds.documentation: One or more AWS account IDs. This parameter is valid only when modifying the loadPermission attribute.

UserGroups.documentation: One or more user groups. This parameter is valid only when modifying the loadPermission attribute.

ProductCodes.documentation: One or more product codes. After you add a product code to an AFI, it can't be removed. This parameter is valid only when modifying the productCodes attribute.

AutoPlacement.documentation: Specify whether to enable or disable auto-placement.

HostIds.documentation: The IDs of the Dedicated Hosts to modify.

Successful.documentation: The IDs of the Dedicated Hosts that were successfully modified.

Unsuccessful.documentation: The IDs of the Dedicated Hosts that could not be modified. Check whether the setting you requested can be used.

Resource.documentation:
The type of resource: bundle | conversion-task | customer-gateway | dhcp-options | elastic-ip-allocation | elastic-ip-association | export-task | flow-log | image | import-task | internet-gateway | network-acl | network-acl-association | network-interface | network-interface-attachment | prefix-list | route-table | route-table-association | security-group | subnet | subnet-cidr-block-association | vpc | vpc-cidr-block-association | vpc-endpoint | vpc-peering-connection | vpn-connection | vpn-gateway.

Alternatively, use the all-current option to include all resource types that are currently within their opt-in period for longer IDs.

UseLongIds.documentation: Indicate whether the resource should use longer IDs (17-character IDs).

PrincipalArn.documentation: The ARN of the principal, which can be an IAM user, IAM role, or the root user. Specify all to modify the ID format for all IAM users, IAM roles, and the root user of the account.

Resource.documentation:
The type of resource: bundle | conversion-task | customer-gateway | dhcp-options | elastic-ip-allocation | elastic-ip-association | export-task | flow-log | image | import-task | internet-gateway | network-acl | network-acl-association | network-interface | network-interface-attachment | prefix-list | route-table | route-table-association | security-group | subnet | subnet-cidr-block-association | vpc | vpc-cidr-block-association | vpc-endpoint | vpc-peering-connection | vpn-connection | vpn-gateway.

Alternatively, use the all-current option to include all resource types that are currently within their opt-in period for longer IDs.

UseLongIds.documentation: Indicates whether the resource should use longer IDs (17-character IDs)

Attribute.documentation: The name of the attribute to modify. The valid values are description, launchPermission, and productCodes.

LaunchPermission.documentation: A new launch permission for the AMI.

OperationType.documentation: The operation type. This parameter can be used only when the Attribute parameter is launchPermission.

ProductCodes.documentation: One or more DevPay product codes. After you add a product code to an AMI, it can't be removed.

UserGroups.documentation: One or more user groups. This parameter can be used only when the Attribute parameter is launchPermission.

UserIds.documentation: One or more AWS account IDs. This parameter can be used only when the Attribute parameter is launchPermission.

Value.documentation: The value of the attribute being modified. This parameter can be used only when the Attribute parameter is description or productCodes.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

SourceDestCheck.documentation: Specifies whether source/destination checking is enabled. A value of true means that checking is enabled, and false means that checking is disabled. This value must be false for a NAT instance to perform NAT.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation:
Modifies the DeleteOnTermination attribute for volumes that are currently attached. The volume must be owned by the caller. If no value is specified for DeleteOnTermination, the default is true and the volume is deleted when the instance is terminated.

To add instance store volumes to an Amazon EBS-backed instance, you must add them when you launch the instance. For more information, see Updating the Block Device Mapping when Launching an Instance in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

DisableApiTermination.documentation: If the value is true, you can't terminate the instance using the Amazon EC2 console, CLI, or API; otherwise, you can. You cannot use this parameter for Spot Instances.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

EbsOptimized.documentation: Specifies whether the instance is optimized for Amazon EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal EBS I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS Optimized instance.

EnaSupport.documentation:
Set to true to enable enhanced networking with ENA for the instance.

This option is supported only for HVM instances. Specifying this option with a PV instance can make it unreachable.

Groups.documentation: [EC2-VPC] Changes the security groups of the instance. You must specify at least one security group, even if it's just the default security group for the VPC. You must specify the security group ID, not the security group name.

InstanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior.documentation: Specifies whether an instance stops or terminates when you initiate shutdown from the instance (using the operating system command for system shutdown).

InstanceType.documentation: Changes the instance type to the specified value. For more information, see Instance Types. If the instance type is not valid, the error returned is InvalidInstanceAttributeValue.

Kernel.documentation: Changes the instance's kernel to the specified value. We recommend that you use PV-GRUB instead of kernels and RAM disks. For more information, see PV-GRUB.

Ramdisk.documentation: Changes the instance's RAM disk to the specified value. We recommend that you use PV-GRUB instead of kernels and RAM disks. For more information, see PV-GRUB.

SriovNetSupport.documentation:
Set to simple to enable enhanced networking with the Intel 82599 Virtual Function interface for the instance.

There is no way to disable enhanced networking with the Intel 82599 Virtual Function interface at this time.

This option is supported only for HVM instances. Specifying this option with a PV instance can make it unreachable.

UserData.documentation: Changes the instance's user data to the specified value. If you are using an AWS SDK or command line tool, base64-encoding is performed for you, and you can load the text from a file. Otherwise, you must provide base64-encoded text.

Value.documentation: A new value for the attribute. Use only with the kernel, ramdisk, userData, disableApiTermination, or instanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior attribute.

InstanceId.documentation: The ID of the instance to be modified.

CapacityReservationSpecification.documentation: Information about the Capacity Reservation targeting option.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Return.documentation: Returns true if the request succeeds; otherwise, it returns an error.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

ClientToken.documentation: A unique, case-sensitive token that you provide to ensure idempotency of your modification request. For more information, see Ensuring Idempotency.

InstanceCreditSpecifications.documentation: Information about the credit option for CPU usage.

SuccessfulInstanceCreditSpecifications.documentation: Information about the instances whose credit option for CPU usage was successfully modified.

UnsuccessfulInstanceCreditSpecifications.documentation: Information about the instances whose credit option for CPU usage was not modified.

GroupName.documentation:
The name of the placement group in which to place the instance. For spread placement groups, the instance must have a tenancy of default. For cluster placement groups, the instance must have a tenancy of default or dedicated.

To remove an instance from a placement group, specify an empty string ("").

HostId.documentation: The ID of the Dedicated Host with which to associate the instance.

InstanceId.documentation: The ID of the instance that you are modifying.

Return.documentation: Is true if the request succeeds, and an error otherwise.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

ClientToken.documentation: Unique, case-sensitive identifier you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. For more information, see Ensuring Idempotency.

LaunchTemplateId.documentation: The ID of the launch template. You must specify either the launch template ID or launch template name in the request.

LaunchTemplateName.documentation: The name of the launch template. You must specify either the launch template ID or launch template name in the request.

DefaultVersion.documentation: The version number of the launch template to set as the default version.

Attachment.documentation: Information about the interface attachment. If modifying the 'delete on termination' attribute, you must specify the ID of the interface attachment.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Groups.documentation: Changes the security groups for the network interface. The new set of groups you specify replaces the current set. You must specify at least one group, even if it's just the default security group in the VPC. You must specify the ID of the security group, not the name.

SourceDestCheck.documentation: Indicates whether source/destination checking is enabled. A value of true means checking is enabled, and false means checking is disabled. This value must be false for a NAT instance to perform NAT. For more information, see NAT Instances in the Amazon Virtual Private Cloud User Guide.

ReservedInstancesIds.documentation: The IDs of the Reserved Instances to modify.

ClientToken.documentation: A unique, case-sensitive token you provide to ensure idempotency of your modification request. For more information, see Ensuring Idempotency.

TargetConfigurations.documentation: The configuration settings for the Reserved Instances to modify.

Attribute.documentation: The snapshot attribute to modify. Only volume creation permissions can be modified.

CreateVolumePermission.documentation: A JSON representation of the snapshot attribute modification.

GroupNames.documentation: The group to modify for the snapshot.

OperationType.documentation: The type of operation to perform to the attribute.

UserIds.documentation: The account ID to modify for the snapshot.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

ExcessCapacityTerminationPolicy.documentation: Indicates whether running Spot Instances should be terminated if the target capacity of the Spot Fleet request is decreased below the current size of the Spot Fleet.

SpotFleetRequestId.documentation: The ID of the Spot Fleet request.

Return.documentation: Is true if the request succeeds, and an error otherwise.

AssignIpv6AddressOnCreation.documentation:
Specify true to indicate that network interfaces created in the specified subnet should be assigned an IPv6 address. This includes a network interface that's created when launching an instance into the subnet (the instance therefore receives an IPv6 address).

If you enable the IPv6 addressing feature for your subnet, your network interface or instance only receives an IPv6 address if it's created using version 2016-11-15 or later of the Amazon EC2 API.

MapPublicIpOnLaunch.documentation: Specify true to indicate that network interfaces created in the specified subnet should be assigned a public IPv4 address. This includes a network interface that's created when launching an instance into the subnet (the instance therefore receives a public IPv4 address).

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet.

AutoEnableIO.documentation: Indicates whether the volume should be auto-enabled for I/O operations.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Size.documentation:
The target size of the volume, in GiB. The target volume size must be greater than or equal to than the existing size of the volume. For information about available EBS volume sizes, see Amazon EBS Volume Types.

Default: If no size is specified, the existing size is retained.

VolumeType.documentation:
The target EBS volume type of the volume.

Default: If no type is specified, the existing type is retained.

Iops.documentation:
The target IOPS rate of the volume.

This is only valid for Provisioned IOPS SSD (io1) volumes. For more information, see Provisioned IOPS SSD (io1) Volumes.

Default: If no IOPS value is specified, the existing value is retained.

EnableDnsHostnames.documentation:
Indicates whether the instances launched in the VPC get DNS hostnames. If enabled, instances in the VPC get DNS hostnames; otherwise, they do not.

You cannot modify the DNS resolution and DNS hostnames attributes in the same request. Use separate requests for each attribute. You can only enable DNS hostnames if you've enabled DNS support.

EnableDnsSupport.documentation:
Indicates whether the DNS resolution is supported for the VPC. If enabled, queries to the Amazon provided DNS server at the 169.254.169.253 IP address, or the reserved IP address at the base of the VPC network range "plus two" succeed. If disabled, the Amazon provided DNS service in the VPC that resolves public DNS hostnames to IP addresses is not enabled.

You cannot modify the DNS resolution and DNS hostnames attributes in the same request. Use separate requests for each attribute.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

ConnectionNotificationArn.documentation: The ARN for the SNS topic for the notification.

ConnectionEvents.documentation: One or more events for the endpoint. Valid values are Accept, Connect, Delete, and Reject.

ReturnValue.documentation: Returns true if the request succeeds; otherwise, it returns an error.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

ResetPolicy.documentation: (Gateway endpoint) Specify true to reset the policy document to the default policy. The default policy allows full access to the service.

PolicyDocument.documentation: (Gateway endpoint) A policy document to attach to the endpoint. The policy must be in valid JSON format.

AddRouteTableIds.documentation: (Gateway endpoint) One or more route tables IDs to associate with the endpoint.

RemoveRouteTableIds.documentation: (Gateway endpoint) One or more route table IDs to disassociate from the endpoint.

AddSubnetIds.documentation: (Interface endpoint) One or more subnet IDs in which to serve the endpoint.

RemoveSubnetIds.documentation: (Interface endpoint) One or more subnets IDs in which to remove the endpoint.

AddSecurityGroupIds.documentation: (Interface endpoint) One or more security group IDs to associate with the network interface.

RemoveSecurityGroupIds.documentation: (Interface endpoint) One or more security group IDs to disassociate from the network interface.

PrivateDnsEnabled.documentation: (Interface endpoint) Indicate whether a private hosted zone is associated with the VPC.

Return.documentation: Returns true if the request succeeds; otherwise, it returns an error.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

AcceptanceRequired.documentation: Indicate whether requests to create an endpoint to your service must be accepted.

AddNetworkLoadBalancerArns.documentation: The Amazon Resource Names (ARNs) of Network Load Balancers to add to your service configuration.

RemoveNetworkLoadBalancerArns.documentation: The Amazon Resource Names (ARNs) of Network Load Balancers to remove from your service configuration.

Return.documentation: Returns true if the request succeeds; otherwise, it returns an error.

RemoveAllowedPrincipals.documentation: The Amazon Resource Names (ARN) of one or more principals. Permissions are revoked for principals in this list.

AccepterPeeringConnectionOptions.documentation: Information about the VPC peering connection options for the accepter VPC.

RequesterPeeringConnectionOptions.documentation: Information about the VPC peering connection options for the requester VPC.

InstanceTenancy.documentation: The instance tenancy attribute for the VPC.

State.documentation: Indicates whether detailed monitoring is enabled. Otherwise, basic monitoring is enabled.
